Blog.post: Bob Patterson will be Shutterline's Photo of the Day judge for roughly the next three months (minus a week here or there)... Continue to send your POTD entries to the same email address. Good luck, Bob!

Photo of the Day for Feb. 16, 2003 -- The Lady in Red Photographer: Margaret Schmidt Comments: A photo I've been playing with trying to get that old time portrait look with a charcoal look... Camera used: Canon D60 Geo. location: Bob's comments: Well, this is my first choice for POTD and boy o boy was it a difficult choice or what? There are some SUPERB submissions, really there are. How you guys maintain your standards day in and day out, I really don't know. In the end, my choice was The Lady In Red - there's a sort of mystery about her that's simply beguiling.

"The photos suck." No, the Photo of the Day winners are great actually, but some of you have expressed honest concern about the image quality being shown here. Starting with the next POTD winner published (on 2/16), the image you see here will be just a "thumbnail" -- you click on it to view the full-size image. I am sorry that I haven't been doing that yet, it's still a new system for me but I think it will be cool to have all of the POTD winners for the week on this one page. Then, you can just click on the image if you're interested in seeing it at the highest resolution. Cool?

Photo of the Day for Feb. 15, 2003 -- A Moment of Beauty Photographer: Deborah Walmsley Comments: There are so many beautiful sunset's here in Idaho, and I've often tried capturing their beauty, but always from my front yard. On this evening, we hurried out on a venture looking for a new and better location to capture this sunset. The area we found in this photo is in Eagle, Idaho. This was a very special day, and was important to me to photograph this sunset, as it was my dear Mother's Birthday. Camera used: Sony Cybershot Geo. location: Idaho David's comments: Great sunset shot, Deborah -- I've seen plenty of them in the past, they get boring after a while, but the rich tones and the interesting foreground sets this one apart and makes it unique. A deserving win! (by the way, I really enjoyed a few of the other entries received today, will roll some over to the next day's contest!)

Photo of the Day for Feb. 14, 2003 -- Comfy Photographer: Jim Carper Comments: This shot was taken at Animal Kingdom at Walt Disney World on Feb 8, 2003 using a Canon EOS D30. Camera used: Canon EOS D30 Geo. location: Florida David's comments: Great wildlife photograph, Jim! The pose and framing of this image is excellent as well. Just to let everyone know, POTD entries are still being accepted at the same email address (shutterlinephotos AT yahoo dot com) and a link to submit photographs is also available within the Premium Member Control Panel . Don't stop sending your daily entry just because you haven't won in a while -- be persistent and continue to take creative shots!

Photo of the Day for Feb. 13, 2003 -- Ruffled Feathers Photographer: J. Pedersen Comments: Not the zoo this time, Sea World. LOL Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Geo. location: California David's comments: Good coloration in the background and an excellent subject. Now I know how Cheryl feels, it is ridiculously difficult to pick the winner of these contests... We had another animal entry that was awesome as well, in addition to some great landscape shots. If only we could have two winners a day (hmm...)

Great! The upgrade to the Photo of the Day service was successful... Now you can view each daily winner from this page. I think that will make things easier. Also, I think that we all need to give a huge thanks to Cheryl Meisel for being our POTD judge up until now for over a year. That's awesome, and she has done a tremendous amount of work to help Shutterline get to where it is today. (come back here every 24 hours to view the latest winning photo, starting on 2/13)

Photo of the Day for Saturday, Feb.22nd, 2003 -- Wolves urlLink Photographer: Mariette Geest Comments: by luck I could make a picture of these wolves. those eyes.... Camera used: Olympus C-730 UZ Judge's comments: I think Mariette says it all - it's the eyes, the eyes! This is the first thumbnail POTD that we've tried. You should be able to click on it and be taken to Mariette's fullsize submission

Photo of the Day for Friday, Feb. 21st 2003 -- Lamp Photographer: Lyn Winans Comments: None ... Camera used: Olympus 2020 Geo. location: Minden, ON Judge's comments: The contrasting colours in Lyn's picture are outstanding. It's a lovely study. Not being a gardener of any description - well I mow a mean lawn! - what I'd really like to know is what sort of flower it is !

Photo of the Day for Feb. 20, 2003 -- Down to the Waterline Photographer: Jum Carper Comments: There's a little spot where some shrimpboats dock in Mayport that makes a nice backdrop for various birds flying by, including various herons, egrets, osprey, and of course, plenty of brown pelicans. Date 19th February 2003 Camera used: Canon EOS D30 Geo. location: Mayport, Florida Judge's comments: The Bird Man of Florida does it again! Amongst some truly superb entries for POTD, Jim's brilliant capture stood out. I've no idea Jim, quite how you manage these shots. The way I see it is that the birds see you coming and just start queueing up to pose for your camera because they know they'll be a POTD
Photo of the Day for Feb. 18, 2003 -- He's a Hoot Photographer: Deborah Walmsley Judge's comments: He's back !! My apologies for the error Deborah

Photo of the Day for Feb. 19, 2003 -- Sedona Colors Photographer: Janet Pedersen Comments: Our motel outside wall in Sedona, Arizona. Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Geo. location: Sedona, Arizona Judge's comments: This is one of those photographs that you keep going back to, over and over again. The contrasts of light and dark, the remarkable textures, the lines that are in it, all just make it compulsive. I'm almost sure that if I touched it, I could feel it ...

Photo of the Day for Feb. 17, 2003 -- Corny Reflections Photographer: Cheryl Meisel Comments: Beautiful indian corn made pretty reflections Camera used: Sony 707 Geo. location: MI Judge's comments: This is called Corny Reflections so I looked up "corny" in the dictionary. Part of it says "dull and tiresome" and that's the very LAST thing that can be said about this picture. It's full of colour and every time I look at it I see something different in it. I could look at it for a long while. In fact, it's time to change my desktop picture so Cheryl ... if I may? o:)

Photo of the Day for March 1, 2003 -- City Sunset Reflections urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: I took this late in the day in mid September. I had taken some shots and walked up the street and when I returned, I saw all these wonderful golden tones bouncing off all the buildings and I shot it some more. Camera used: Fuji FP 2800 Geo. location: Philadelphia, PA Judge's comments: I love the 'golden tones' of the reflections. An excellent city shot, not your ordinary cityscape. Reminder: You can click on the small thumbnail image to load the full-size image. Also, if you're not yet a member, now's a pretty good time to urlLink join us .

Photo of the Day for Feb. 28, 2003 -- Sunset - Martin Dies Park urlLink Photographer: James Powers Comments: This is a sunset shot from a park at what's locally known as "Dam B." It's a Dam and reservoir near Jasper, Texas. Four dams were planned in the 1940s. Only Dam "B" was built. Camera used: Canon D60, Canon 20mm 2.8 EF Geo. location: Texas Judge's comments: A perfect sunset photo. I love the rich colors and the horizon line. Very deserving win!

Photo of the Day for Thursday, Feb.27th, 2003 -- The Diner urlLink Photographer: Kay Prather Comments: Entrance to a diner in South, La. I like the colors, lines and simplicity.. Camera used: Nikon CoolPix 995 Judge's comments: I agree with Kay that the colours and the lines and the overall simplicity of the photograph really make it memorable. I especially liked the way my eyes were drawn, through the lines to the door. An intriguing image which raises the question is "What awaits you behind the door?". You'd just HAVE to go in and find out.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, Feb.26th, 2003 -- Thief! urlLink Photographer: James Powers Comments: > We were enjoying a picnic Sunday at a small roadside park near here when a squirrel decided to raid the bag of Cheeto's left on the table. He made a quick run up a tree about 10 foot from the table and enjoyed his treat. Camera used: Canon D60, Canon 75-300mm lens Geo. location: Texas Judge's comments: This must be real fun for the squirrel - look at the twinkle in it's eyes and that HUGE smile !! If the squirrel is that good at pinching bits and pieces of food from a table, look out for your nuts. ;o)

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, Feb.25th, 2003 -- Arches and Pipes urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: This is the front of the Sanctuary of First Baptist Church of Philadelphia. The interior is beautiful and this is a small portion. We gave a concert here on Saturday night. Camera used: Fuji FP 2600 Geo. location: Philadelphia, PA Judge's comments: Once again, this is a high class photograph which is full of wonderful detail which very much kept my eye occupied way beyond simply looking at it. There's also a "depth" to it which is equally pleasing.

Photo of the Day for Monday, Feb.24th, 2003 -- Layers urlLink Photographer: Gerda Grice Comments: Comment: I took this picture on our cruise in January. I liked the layered look of the roof edges. Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Judge's comments: This is a great capture. The lines of the roofs are just, well, magnetic. And then I found my attention being drawn to somewhere else and suddenly I realised there's a lot, lot more in the picture than was apparent at first.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, Feb.23rd, 2003 -- Bench with a View urlLink Photographer: Janet Pedersen Comments: Taken at Gull Lake, California Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Geo. location: California Judge's comments: This is the kind of bench that's seen a bit of life. Looking at it makes you wonder how many people have sat there, looking at the wonderful view, and simply enjoying the sun. If that bench could talk, it could tell a tale or two, no doubt of it. It's a totally enchanting photograph

Photo of the Day for Saturday, March 8th, 2003 -- Above the Clouds urlLink Photographer: Richard Bennett Comments: Though I was only standing on a small hill this shot makes it look like I was miles high when I took this. Camera used: Sony MVC FD97 Geo. location: Idaho Judge's comments: If you take time out just to look at Richard's photo for a while, all the sounds of the world go away and suddenly, you're up there with the eagle. Try it! But if you wanted some mood music to go along with the image, what about the Jennifer Warnes - Joe Cocker song from "An Officer and a Gentleman"? The lyrics could easily have been inspired by this image. Mind you Richard, I really do hope you weren't "miles high" when you took it ...;o)

Photo of the Day for Friday, March 7th, 2003 -- Shadows on the Path urlLink Photographer: Janet Pedersen Comments: This was taken in Feb. '03 at the Grand Canyon. Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Geo. location: Grand Canyon Judge's comments: There are, for me, two big things about this photograph. First of course is the subject of the title, the Shadows which are on the path. It's great the way Janet has managed to use shadows to move your eye right through the picture instead of the fence itself which would, I think, normally have been the case. A clever idea.The second thing that makes it a POTD for me is the really good use of the "digital darkroom" to create the sepia effect. The result is an extremely powerful image which may not have been quite as strong in colour. Great stuff all round.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, March 6th, 2003 -- JudyJudyJudy urlLink Photographer: Jim Carper Comments: This Bonobo ape's expression reminded me of Goober's famous impersonation of Cary Grant on the old "Andy Griffith Show"......and that's where I got the title for this shot. Camera used: Canon EOS D30 w/Canon 100-400mm L lens Geo. location: Jacksonville, Florida Judge's comments: I don't know about JudyJudyJudy: all I can think of is "JimJimJim"!! This is quite simply an amusing, amazing shot. Congratulations Jim on being there to take it. Wonderful.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, March 5th, 2003 - - Tropical Colours urlLink Photographer: Gerda Grice Comments: We saw lots of these pretty, light, bright colours when we were in the Caribbean the last week in January. I'm afraid I can't remember for sure on exactly which island we saw this particular building, unfortunately. I have great memories of the week we spent on our holiday. I just wish that my memory for where we saw what we saw was great, too! Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Geo. location: Somewhere in the Caribbean Judge's comments: Gerda's photograph makes me feel, well, jealous!! :o) I'm joking of course ... Heck, no I'm not!! I am jealous - of the sunshine and the blue, blue sky and all those beautiful, beautiful colours of the Caribbean which have been so expertly captured here by Gerda. Just looking at the picture makes you feel the warmth of the sun on your back ...

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, March 4th, 2003 -- Jewels urlLink Photographer: Pat McGinnis Comments: Saltwater fish in tank Camera used: Sony MVC FD97 Judge's comments: I reckon fish really are difficult things to capture with a camera so for me that makes Pat's photograph just great. Apart from anything else, fish never seem to be where you want them to be! The colours are great and the overall feeling of motion generated by the weed in the background is a big plus as well.

Photo of the Day for March 3, 2003 -- "Let Me In" urlLink Photographer: Jim Carper Comments: Photo of a Bush Viper taken March 3, 2003 at the Jacksonville, Florida, Zoo using a Canon EOS D30 w/ Canon 50mm 2.5 Macro lens. Camera used: Canon EOS D30 Geo. location: Florida Judge's comments: Another great wildlife shot from Jim! I liked the water droplets, a nice touch. Also, thanks for providing a useful description -- telling us what kind of lens you used is always a good thing to do.

Photo of the Day for March 2, 2003 -- It'll Do Your Body Good urlLink Photographer: Deborah Walmsley Comments: Grocery store dairy isle. Camera used: Sony Cybershot DSC-F707 Geo. location: not provided Judge's comments: There were a lot of great photos submitted for today's contest, but something struck me about this photo. Maybe it's the colors or the geometry. Or, maybe it's the amazing variety of yogurt. Anyway, it's a unique shot -- congratulations.

Photo of the Day for Saturday, March 15th 2003 -- Patterns urlLink Photographer: Cheyrl Tessens Comments: What caught my interest for this shot were the similiar colors and patterns between the dried yellow roses and the tray they were setting on. Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Geo. location: Holly, MI Judge's comments: I can't do any more than agree with Cheryl. There is a striking similarity and it's that which initially catches the eye. But there's more than that as well. I actually ran Cheryl's photo through Elements and brightened it up - and surprisingly, it then sort of "fails" if you see what I mean. I think it's because there's also an overall mood to the image which is lost in processing it. I like it a lot and as it is.

Photo of the Day for Friday, March 14th 2003 -- A Window Cleaner's Nightmare urlLink Photographer: Franziska Lang Comments: Taken of a tall office building in Tyson's corner. Desaturated all color channels except blue. Increased saturation of blue. Crop, resize, unsharpen mask. Camera used: Nikon D100 Geo. location: Virginia Judge's comments: What a truly staggering image. I was taken with it as soon as I saw it. I really do like the way Franziska has created the whole effect of perspective and colour - and the lack of it - combined in the one photograph. And the explanation of how it was done is there for all of us to share. Great, great stuff.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, March 13th 2003 -- Woodpecker urlLink Photographer: Doug Mauck Comments: > I used an Army surplus camo net over a stepladder as a blind to get close to the bird feeder. It looked dumb, but it worked. Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Geo. location: Topeka, Kansas Judge's comments: There are times when dedication to a cause just have to have it's rewards and this is one of them! What a terrific idea Doug! - and what a result! It's simply wonderful I don't know about looking dumb but if this is the sort of capture you can get then more power to your elbow!!

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, March 12th, 2003 -- Dawn's Magic urlLink Photographer: Sue Shirk Comments: This is my back yard in the very early morning just as the sun was rising. It gave such a pretty color and light in the forest. Camera used: Nikon Coolpix 995 Geo. location: Not known ... Judge's comments: This really is a magical picture, full of contrasts, lines, light, shadows - and a mysterious glow in the background! It's also quite amazing how Sue found enough light at that time of the morning to get the image ... did you have to take manual control of the camera Sue, or was it done on a programmed setting? Share your secret? :o)

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, March 11th, 2003 -- Snow Leopard urlLink Photographer: Deborah Walmsley Comments: None .... Camera used: Sony Cybershot DSC-F707 Geo. location: Boise City Zoo in Idaho Judge's comments: The eye's have it!! The leopard really does look like it's looking down it's nose at you! It's a "How dare you disturb me" look! A great shot of a lovely - and elusive - animal.

Photo of the Day for Monday, March 10th, 2003 -- Centre Glory urlLink Photographer: Gerda Grice Comments: This is a flower picture I took this past summer. I modified it to some extent at the time, and then played around with it a bit more a few days ago. Camera used: Olympus C-3020Z Judge's comments: There's something about really good digital art that I find fascinating. And Gerda's picture is just that: really good digital art. I think this is an example of there being no such thing as a "bad" photograph as it proves what amazing effects can be achieved in the digital darkroom.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, March 9th, 2003 -- Empty Pastures urlLink Photographer: Lyn Winans Comments: .... none .... Camera used: Olympus E20 Judge's comments: I really liked the way Lyn has captured the light in her photograph and especially the way it's reflected off the snow and ice and the metal. There really is an "emptiness" about Lyn's picture whilst at the same time the light suggests it's at it's end too. A well constructed and gently provocative image. Great.

Photo of the Day for Saturday, March 22nd 2003 -- Perched urlLink Photographer: Franziska Lang Comments: A tiny butterfly/moth (?) that hardly ever sat still and was very sensitive to any kind of movement. I chased the poor thing around the yard all afternoon before I got a couple of shots of it. It could've made life much easier for both of us! ;) Used the Canon PS Pro90 at full zoom with macro attachment for this one. Camera used: Canon PS Pro90 IS Geo. location: Virginia Judge's comments: Franziska's final image just has to bereward for her dedication! Chasing a butterfly all afternoon is above and beyond the call of duty in my humble opinion!! At the end though, it really is worth it. Incredible detail, depth, colour - it's all there. I for one am very glad that the little devil finally agreed to pose for the picture to be taken. I reckon every single one of us has tried to do exactly what Franziska has managed - and failed ! A very worthy POTD.

Photo of the Day for Friday, March 21st 2003 -- A Study in Blue urlLink Photographer: Ron Case Comments: This is a picture of the Wellsville Mountains in Northern Utah. It was taken around noon on a very bright day which still had a slight smoggy overcast to it. This gave everything a bluish tint to it. This is a composition of 4 pictures which I stitched together. The shots were handheld. I used Photoshop Elements to enhance the bluish cast. Camera used: Kodak DC3400 Geo. location: Wellsville, UT Judge's comments: Today's choice almost picks itself as it's the first panoramic view that has been submitted for the "new" way of presenting the POTD from the Shutterline site but in any case, it is a glorious example of that type of photograph. On top of that, Ron's explanation of how he achieved it - making it look very simple - is a big plus. Tremendous work Ron.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, March 20th 2003 -- Red Light District urlLink Photographer: Cheryl Meisel Comments: Found this interesting building in downtown Toledo Ohio. Camera used: Sony Cybershot DSC-F707 Geo. location: Toledo, Ohio Judge's comments: I think this is a really, really intriguing image which seems to set all sorts of questions. There's definitely a certain "je ne sais quoi" about it - something you can't quite put your finger on, if you know what I mean. There's a mysterious quality about it and the door seems to be, well, very inviting ... I think it proves that photography can inspire the mind as well as entertain the eye and sooth the soul. Great, great spot and capture Cheryl.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, March 19th 2003 -- Backlit Floral urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: Got a new Fuji FP 2800 and went a little crazy with flowers at the florists! Camera used: Fuji FinePix 2800 Geo. location: Philadelphia PA Judge's comments: A little crazy Robert? But we're glad you did because you could then share this great photograph with us all ! I especially liked the great splash of colour it presents. I have no idea how hard you had to work at getting the backlighting working or what you used to do it, but it's mighty effective. Share your secrets?

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, March 18th 2003 -- Misty Sunrise urlLink Photographer: Mariette Geest Comments: Don't know, the light through the tree, the morning fog on the ground and the rock formation. Actually the rocks are an ancient graveyard and are called 'hunebeds'. It is something special here in the Netherlands and with the light and fog ... spooky! Camera used: Olympus C-730 UZ Geo. location: The Netherlands Judge's comments: Indeed Mariette, this is a "spooky" image. In particular I really do like the way you've been able to capture the light which seems to "bounce" off everything, especially the mist.

Photo of the Day for Monday, March 17th 2003 -- Autumn on the Niagara River urlLink Photographer: Sherry March Comments: None .... Camera used: Nikon Coolpix 995 Geo. location: The Niagara River Judge's comments: If ever there was a photo that captured Nature's extremes in one, Sherry's is it. The beauty of Nature in the colours of the trees, her fury in the raging river and her threats in the sky, all there for us to see in one image. Sherry, what a shot!

Photo of the Day for Sunday, 16th March 2003 -- Rush urlLink Photographer: Lyn Winans Comments: None .... Camera used: Olympus E20 Geo. location: Minden, ON, Canada Judge's comments: The simplest is often the most striking and has by far the biggest impact. This marvellous, wonderful composition by Lyn is one of those. Just breathtaking, Lyn.

Photo of the Day for Saturday, March 29th 2003 -- Old Puppy urlLink Photographer: Lyn Winans Comments: None ... Camera used: Olympus E20 Geo. location: Minden, ON, Canada Judge's comments: I think Lyn's photo is quite, quite wonderful. It's so good, I feel I ought to be able to reach out and tickle the "Old Puppy" - and what an inspired title that is! - under the chin. Beautiful detail in a picture that really is, quite genuinely, alive. So much so that it looks like the old guy is going to leap out of the screen!

Photo of the Day for Friday, March 28th 2003 -- Bright Faces urlLink Photographer: Janet Pedersen Comments: None ... Camera used: Sony DSC F505 Geo. location: Not known Judge's comments: Janet's photo really is a lovely study of Spring in all it's glory. You can see the colours and the light but you can also feel the warmth of the sunshine that's reflected. Magical.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, March 27th 2003 -- Relax urlLink Photographer: Margaret Schmidt Comments: None ... Camera used: Canon D60 Judge's comments: In these deeply troubled times, Margaret's picture should serve as profound advice to all those who lead us, wherever we are in the world. "Relax ..." says it all. And apart from that, the photo just appealed to my sense of humour! Loved it!!

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, March 26th 2003 -- Red White and Blue urlLink Photographer: Kaye Grogan Comments: This is the front of an OfficeMax building. I noticed the red trim with the blue sky and white clouds and I immediately thought of a "patriotic" theme. Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Geo. location: Martinsville, Virginia Judge's comments: I wouldn't want to comment on the theme that Kaye saw and which prompted her to take this wonderful image but I was struck by everything about it. In particular I really liked the lines and the angles and the colour and the "sharpness" of the light in it. I'm simply very glad she saw it!

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, March 25th 2003 -- Village by the Grange urlLink Photographer: Gerda Grice Comments: The Village by the Grange is a small mall close to the AGO (the Art Gallery of Ontario--the public art gallery for our province). I took this photo in the very early evening. The lights had just come on and it wasn't yet really dark. The camera was hand held. I'd have used a tripod if I'd had one with me, but I didn't. I was quite happy with how this turned out, though. Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Geo. location: Canada Judge's comments: It's amazing that Gerda managed to capture this image with just a hand held camera! I was really knocked out with the colours in the photograph which I'm sure wouldn't have been anything like so strong if it had been taken in the middle of the day. A time and a place for everything!!

Photo of the Day for Monday, March 24th 2003 -- Radial urlLink Photographer: Jim Carper Comments: Well, with a rack like that, how can any guy resist, eh? Oh, the joys of mating season! :^) I suppose this would be better without the branches protruding, and most would prefer it with the feet in the frame, but for me, the point of this shot is the fanning out of the plumage, so I wanted a tighter crop. Photo of this Great Egret taken at the St. Augustine Alligator Farm. Camera used: Canon EOS D30 w/Canon 100-400mm lens Geo. location: St. Augustine, Florida Taken: March 21, 2003 Judge's comments: I agree with Jim. This is one of the times when the "rules" of photography (are there really such things?) should get ripped up for the sake of the picture. This way we get to see what must be a very rare display instead of worrying about the "complete" picture. A great shot and a very worthy POTD.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, March 23rd 2003 -- Chrome urlLink Photographer: Lesley Mattuchio Comments: Comment: It's that time of year again when the boys take our their summer toys...motorcycles! Camera used: Canon 10D Geo. location: Melrose, MA Judge's comments: A great study picked out by the very talented eye of Lesley. I really do like the depth in the photograph and the overall way that it keeps my eyes busy, if you know what I mean.

Photo of the Day for Saturday, 5th April 2003 -- Family Affairs urlLink Photographer: Cheryl Meisel Comments: Taken at Erie Marsh in MI. just before they BOOKED! lol Camera used: Sony 707 Geo. location: Erie, Michigan Judge's comments: An interesting black & white photo. I didn't even see the little geese to the right at first, they blended in so well!

Photo of the Day for Friday, 4th April 2003 -- The Net urlLink Photographer: Janet Pedersen Comments: None .... Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Judge's comments: A very striking submission from Janet. I really did take to the way that the photograph is "layered" with, from the bottom, the beach, the foreshore, the sea and finally the sky. All enhanced by the positioning of the net and it's shadow. And to be honest, I really did think that this was a "mood" photograph. I can't quite put my finger on it, but there's a definite "feel" to it. It's one that I keep coming back to, just to look at and sort of get lost in. A terrific image, Janet - congratulations.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, 3rd April 2003 -- Puddle Deconstructed Construction urlLink Photographer: Gerda Grice Comments: This is a a reflection in a big puddle left by melted ice in the neighbourhood skating ring/wading pool. What's reflected is a condo apartment tower under construction. I liked the way the breaks in the puddle + the sun created a sort of fairytale glow + left gaps in the reflection of the almost finished building Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Judge's comments: Today's POTD is really in the top class. It's an amazing image in so many ways, not least of which is the fact that it has to be spotted for it's potential in the first place! The contrasts and the changes in light in the photograph really are quite staggering. It's also a photograph that in a sense is like one of those "what do you see when you stare at the centre spot" type things (spectrograms?). First you see the water of the puddle, then the building, then the ripples on the water, then the building again ... Gerda, this is a really, really clever photograph and I'm very glad you submitted it to Shutterline.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, 2nd April 2003 -- Send Help! I've been Macroed! urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: Well, I just had an idea and I went with it. Camera used: Fuji FP 2800 Geo. location: Philadelphia, PA Judge's comments: For me, one of the great things about digital photography is what can be done with an image after the shutter goes and Rob's image is a great example of that! This is a huge amount of fun - and I can promise you, I laughed out loud when I first saw it! I'm glad you went with the idea Rob; amongst all the gloom that's around at the moment this was one bright spot and I'm positive we can all do with that.

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, 1st April 2003 -- Compartments urlLink Photographer: Franziska Lang Comments: Obsessive-compulsive behavior? :) Camera used: Nikon D100 Geo. location: Virginia Judge's comments: One of the things about having the pleasure of doing this job each day is that I am continuously staggered at what it is you guys see in the world around you! Franziska's POTD is a brilliant example of what I mean. It's got colour, lines, a depth, it keeps my eyes busy and it's a statement too, picked up in the title that Franziska gave it. I did chuckle at that because we've all met them haven't we? Congratulations Franziska.

Photo of the Day for Monday, 31st March 2003 -- I can't believe it's not Butter! urlLink Photographer: Jim Carper Comments: From the butterfly exhibit at the Jacksonville, Florida, Zoo Camera used: Canon EOS 10D w/Canon 50mm macro 2.5 lens Geo. location: Jacksonville, Florida Judge's comments: Just like Lesley's bee yesterday, Jim's butterfly is quite simply a fantastic image. The detail that's been captured and the depth field is quite amazing. A very different photograph from his more normal birds, this one shows Jim is also very sensitive to what can be seen close up. Another stunner.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, March 30th 2003 -- Harbinger of Sting urlLink Photographer: Lesley Mattuchio Comments: A little friend to welcome Spring in with her head full of pollen! Camera used: Canon 10D Geo. location: Melrose, MA Judge's comments: A great macro shot! 'Struth Lesley, you can almost see the bee thinking! And I bet it's saying "Excuse me! Do you mind? I'm eating!" :o) Great detail + great colour + great depth = great photograph. A stunner.

Photo of the Day for Saturday, 12th April 2003 -- Spring Mirror urlLink Photographer: Lyn Winans Comments: None ... Camera used: Olympus E20 Geo. location: Minden, ON, Canada Judge's comments: The last of Winter ... the first of Spring! It's the contrasts - in Seasons! - that make up the appeal in Lyn's photo. Then there's the way the water leads the eye through the ice, along the reflected line of Spring, towards something better than the ice and apparent promises of warmth to come. A terrific composition.

Photo of the Day for Friday, 11th April 2003 -- Seed Weed urlLink Photographer: Cheryl Meisel Comments: B&W of a weed flower. I would assume a bird dropped the seed as it was all alone and growing in a strange place. Camera used: Sony 707 Geo. location: Erie, MI Judge's comments: I don't know what others think of course, but it strikes me that a big problem with black and white images is that they have to be done exceptionally well to make an impression on anyone. Well, Cheryl's photo is exactly that: exceptional. On top of which, it makes a lovely contrast when seen side by side with the images of the two previous days. Well seen, Cheryl.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, 10th April 2003 -- After the Rain urlLink Photographer: Franziska Lang Comments: No need for the spray bottle with all the April showers at the moment :) Camera used: Nikon D100 Geo. location: Virginia Judge's comments: Today's POTD is one of those that gives me the feeling that if I touched the screen my fingers would be wet! And I'm equally sure that I'd be able to detect that just-after-the-rain smell that's always there. Great depth, detail and colours that work very well with each other. It's a really lovely image Franziska and congratulations.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, 9th April 2003 -- Moonlight Glow urlLink Photographer: Carol VanHook Comments: Here is a beautiful rose to mark a special celebration...honoring our daughter's year in her sports program. A way to preserve this memory is with a picture! Camera used: SonyCSF-707 Geo. location: Iowa Judge's comments: I totally agree with Carol that a photograph, sensitively taken and treated, is exactly the right way to record any occasion. And you'll all know that I'm rather taken with "digital darkroom" work and what has been done with today's POTD, particularly the effect of a diffused glow, is simply ace. Congratulations on the picture Carol, and to your daughter for her achievement.

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, 8th April 2003 -- Going Up urlLink Photographer: Janet Pedersen Comments: This was taken at the Horton Plaza Mall in San Diego. Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Geo. location: San Diego Judge's comments: Janet's photo is full of almost everything I would think anyone would want to see in a photograph. There's light, lines, angles, reflections, contrasts and without any doubt, colours all in there. I was struck by the feeling of motion as well, which I feel was achieved by the person on the elevator. If you didn't get this posed for you Janet, it's a wonderful capture: if you did get it posed - it's a wonderful shot anyway! Loved it.

Photo of the Day for Monday, 7th April 2003 -- Wanna Dive? urlLink Photographer: Mariette Geest Comments: this beach with its beautful colors made me long for a holiday. I was so happy that the colors of the sea were also visibile on the picture Camera used: Olympus C-730 UZ Geo. location: Altea - Spain Judge's comments: What a scrumptious photograph! Beautiful colours and a stunning view over the Mediterranean Sea - I can feel the wind in my hair and taste the salt on my lips! Great.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, 6th April 2003 -- Gumballs urlLink Photographer: Deborah Walmsley Comments: This gumball machine was standing next to the check-out counter at our favorite movie rental store. Seeing how colorful it was, I just had to take a photo (no matter how crazy everyone thought I was!) Camera used: Sony Cybershot DSC-F707 Geo. location: not provided Judge's comments: The colors are "delicious." No, seriously though, this is a good shot and a deserving win.

Photo of the Day for Saturday, 19th April 2003 -- A Long Drink of Water urlLink Photographer: Janet Pedersen Comments: Just another day at the Zoo Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Judge's comments: A gorgeous coloured flamingo and a well constructed photo. And then there's the additional joy of a very subtle play on words in the title that Janet has given it. Marvellous.

Photo of the Day for Friday, 18th April 2003 -- This Old Shoe urlLink Photographer: Deborah Walmsley Comments: My daughter had one of those "spur-of-the-moment" desire to buy something small and furry... this is the one little rat she almost bought, until she experienced the pleasures of what one is capable of doing on her hand while holding it. Camera used: Sony Cybershot DSC-F707 Taken: 17th April 2003 Judge's comments: Deborah's photograph is simply one of those that demands to be seen be as many people as possible!! It's a charming and a fun picture and I'm sure everyone will agree. Congratulations Deborah, on a wonderful capture.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, 17th April 2003 -- My Shadow and I urlLink Photographer: Franziska Lang Comments: This tulip is growing almost horizontally over my concrete door-step. I used yellow cardboard to hide the concrete. Camera used: Nikon D100 Geo. location: Virgina Judge's comments: A terrific photo by Franziska. It's the idea that the shadow is far, far more important than the "real" subject that appealed to both my visual sense and my sense of humour. I swear that the shadow is yawning .. a sort of "yeah-I've heard-all-this-before" look !! And the lines of it's "hat"!! A real eye-catching treat in every respect.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, 16th April 2003 -- Optical Illusion urlLink Photographer: Gerda Grice Comments: It looks like there are 3 levels in the picture, doesn't it? There aren't. There's just one. The illusion that there are more is created by the shadows of our mesh, vertical venetian blinds. Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Judge's comments: Really clever Gerda, it really is. I was also taken with the way the light through the glass has created a surreal red landscape that helps make it look like the glass may even be floating a little. And the lines and the shadows as well ... a great shot.

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, 15th April 2003 -- Pale in the Sky urlLink Photographer: Lesley Mattuchio Comments: Late afternoon this past Saturday I noticed the moon pale agaisnt the blue sky and it looked so soft and silvery, yet I could see some craters and thought it was really neat looking. Camera used: Canon 10D Geo. location: Melrose, MA Judge's comments: Everything about todays choice for POTD seems to me and my un-educated eye, to be just right. I especially liked the way Lesley has managed to "frame" the moon with the branches. A great image that could only be captured because the camera was ready and at hand !!

Photo of the Day for Monday, 14th April 2003 -- Mom, Bobby Said I'm Adopted urlLink Photographer: Jim Carper Comments: Recently hatched Great Egrets photographed at the Alligator Farm Camera used: Canon EOS 10d w/Canon 100-400mm lens Geo. location: St. Augustine, Florida Judge's comments: Amongst all the tremendous work that Jim has produced, to my mind this just has to be by far and away the best yet. A wonderful photograph of a magical scene graced with a title that genuinely tickled my sense of humour. A moment in time captured for all of us to relish.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, 13th April 2003 -- Carousel urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: WOW! NOT PHILADELPHIA OR EVEN PA! That's right! I went to Saratoga Springs last Summer to sing in a Beethoven Ninth Symphony with the Philadelphia Orchestra. In our down time after the morning rehearsal and before the evening performance, I got to roam around Saratoga Springs. The park there was quite nice, but it was a brilliant, sunny, hot day. I beat the sun when I could and one place was at the Carousel House. I took a few shoots there and chose one to do a little DA. The colors were not very vibrant in the original shot. After normal processing, I used the ChromaSolarize Filter from Flaming Pear. That made the colors zing. To give it, as Gerda would call it a "painterly effect", I used the Rough Pastels Filter in Photo Shop Elements. Some cloning was done to remove large areas of black on the floor of the carousel from ChromaSolarize Filter and I cloned some green in the mirror by the horses on the right to cover up the photographer known as RoB. Camera used: Fuji FP 2800 Geo. location: Saratoga Springs, NY Judge's comments: Today's lesson is: never, ever disregard a digital photograph! Well !! .. Other than that, here's nothing I can add to it - outside of I think this is fabulous!!! And something which is very, very different. Terrific!! Love it.

Photo of the Day for Saturday, 26th April 2003 -- A matter of Pi urlLink Photographer: Kathy Cunningham Comments: Close-up of tools for calculating Pi----something to do with circles. Camera used: Sony DSC-F55 Geo. location: Forks, Washington Judge's comments: Today's POTD is a great still life study. I fell for the overall composition but the way all the lines seem to be able to cut across each other without causing any sort of distraction at all is something I don't remember seeing before. It's a really stunning image.

Photo of the Day for Friday, 25th April 2003 -- Elegant Lilies urlLink Photographer: Gerda Grice Comments: I bought these lilies on Thursday, and I've been taking at least a few pictures of them every day since then. Now, all three flowers are fully open, and they look great. I also found the stage we see in this picture very appealing: one of flowers open, the next just about to open and the 3rd still some time away from opening. Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Geo. location: Canada Judge's comments: A stunning image of Nature in all it's most colourful glory. I feel Gerda has got it absolutely right with the word "elegant". It's an elegant photograph of beautiful, elegant flowers, all elegantly presented against a background that significantly adds to the overall picture. It's a total eye-catcher and a real treat to have as POTD.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, 24th April 2003 -- It's not time for sweaty palms! urlLink Photographer: Loretta Kent Comments: The photo is a baby possom in the tree by a building on our property in south Texas. Camera used: Sony Mavica FD71 Geo. location: Texas Judge's comments: There are some photographs that are simply irresistable - and this is most certainly one of them! A gorgeous subject handled and presented with great skill by Loretta.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, 23rd April 2003 -- A Warm Glow urlLink Photographer: Kay Prather Comments: A South La Sunset over the marsh.... Camera used: Nikon Cp 995 Geo. location: LA? Judge's comments: Lovely, deep and rich colours and as the title says, the photo gives you a lovely, warm glow ... And from what I understand of the "rules" of photography a perfectly constructed image as well. Congratulations Kay. Now, where was that ice cold beer ? :o)

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, 22nd April 2003 -- Shades of Spring urlLink Photographer: Sue Shirk Comments: These Daisies have the look of several different colors of yellow when placed in the sunlight. Camera used: Nikon Coolpix 995 Judge's comments: Sue is absolutely correct. There's a host of different shades of yellow in her image but it's the depth of all the colours in it that catches the eye. Then there's the way it's been framed and lit and all of it together simply makes it a very appealling image. Another feast of floral delight for us all to enjoy.

Photo of the Day for Monday, 21st April 2003 -- Just Me urlLink Photographer: Lesley Mattuchio Comments: None ... Camera used: Canon 10D Geo. location: Melrose, MA Judge's comments: I reckon that black and white photography is extremely difficult to get right though I have no idea why that should be: it just seems to me to be that way. Perhaps it's because everything has to be right - but that's what Lesley seems to have managed. Self-portraits are a difficult subject in any case (so I'm told!) and then to get the light and the shading correct just makes the whole thing brilliant. Marvellous work Lesley and congratulations again.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, 20th April 2003 -- Tropical Nature urlLink Photographer: Viveca Venegas Comments: None ... Camera used: Nikon CP995 Geo. location: Not Known Judge's comments: Today's POTD is a beautiful view and wouldn't by any means be out of place in a travel brochure. Well framed and well constructed, it's a photograph that makes you wish you were there ...

Photo of the Day for Saturday, 3rd May 2003 -- Taking Flight urlLink Photographer: Lesley Mattuchio Comments: This is one deer as she is sprinting across the path and back into the forest at the Ipswich River Audubon Wildlife Sanctuary. I shot in continous mode and then merged the four images together to show her movement. It's my first attempt at photo stitching. Camera used: Canon EOS 10D Geo. location: Topsfield, MA Judge's comments: Wow! What a great POTD this is! This is the first time I've seen photo stitching done by anyone who I know, if I can put it that way, so a big plus there. What a clever and great technique it is!! First of all, Lesley, you had to be there to get the photographs and I would think that anyone would be grateful just to be able to say they saw the deer run across their path but then, to be quick enough to have the camera ready and THEN to do the post-shooting work that produced this image ... I'm in awe. I truly am.

Photo of the Day for Friday, 2nd May 2003 -- May I Have This Dance urlLink Photographer: Debbie Norton Comments: I think this is a dogwood bloom. Camera used: Olympus C-700 Geo. location: Gainesville, Florida Judge's comments: Today's POTD is a wonderful, marvellous example of Nature and Digital Art being combined to produce what is a truly sensational feast for the eyes. I just adore it. It really is one of the images that I can imagine appearing in a glossy magazine or a "Photo Book" of some sort. Magnificent, Debbie.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, 1st May 2003 -- A Room with a View urlLink Photographer: Deborah Walmsley Comments: After my first set of photo's taken at this Garden Nursery, I was determined to go back and get a shot of this sphere without being able to see my reflection in it, (just everything else.) I'm pretty sure I accomplished this, but then again, maybe I didn't. Camera used: Sony Cybershot DSC-F707 Date: April 28th, 2003 Judge's comments: I really do like Deborah's photograph. It's got so much going on in it that it keeps my eye busy all the time. And I find myself going back to look at it's detail over and over again - and what more could a photographer ask for? And of course, there's the additional challenge of "Spot Deborah" .. A really skilfully constructed picture.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, 30th April 2003 -- Irises and Lilies urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: Bought three bunches of Irises on Saturday and the Lilies on Friday. Combined them in a bouquet. Some unusual colors that together don't look so bad. Camera used: Fuji FP S602 Geo. location: Philadelphia, PA Judge's comments: Robert says " ... don't look so bad." That's one heck of an understatement for sure: they look truly wonderful! What a glorious display of Nature's colours and textures all touched by the most gentle of lights. The whole thing just works for me. Congratulations, Rob.

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, 29th April 2003 -- Magic Carpet Ride urlLink Photographer: Jim Carper Comments: Late afternoon, the pond aerator was on, and I was in position to catch this Great Egret fly past. I wasn't able to get a good focus lock on the bird, but was still pleased with the resulting image. Camera used: Canon EOS 10d w/Canon 100-400mm lens Geo. location: Jarboe Park in Neptune Beach, Florida. Judge's comments: An exceptional photo even by Jim Carper's own high standards. I don't know about the focus and in truth if anything is lost by that I'm not sure I can see it!! The sparkling background really does give the impression of a magical ride on a carpet of light.

Photo of the Day for Monday, 28th April 2003 -- Swimming Turtle urlLink Photographer: Mariette Geest Comments: this beautiful creature was swimming there and I could not resist taking a picture. Nature at its best. Camera used: Olympus C-730 UZ Geo. location: The Netherlands Judge's comments: There's a definite idea of motion in Mariette's picture. You can really feel the turtle swimming. I'm guessing that it was taken in an aquarium rather than "in the wild" and from experience I know how difficult that can be so for me, that just adds to the achievement. A really graceful photograph.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, 27th April 2003 -- The Peacock Bowl urlLink Photographer: Janet Pedersen Comments: A pretty bowl I saw in a shop. The design reminded me of the colors in peacock feathers. Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Judge's comments: A truly gorgeous photograph for today's POTD. Lovely rich light absolutely everywhere your eye wanders, a wonderful background and overall, colours that are hinted at in the most subtle of ways. And a title for the photo that says what Janet saw. Brilliant!!

Photo of the Day for Saturday, 10th May 2003 -- Chasing the Clouds urlLink Photographer: Jack Provolt Comments: Murphy goes for a ride, his favorite thing. Camera used: Sony DSC F717 Judge's comments: You can really see and feel Murphy enjoying his treat! And there's a huge sense of movement in Jack's photograph which I did especially like. Plus, you get the idea that if the driver went just a little quicker, Murphy might ... just ... get .... that ..... next ..... cloud !!! Great shot and congratulations Jack.

Photo of the Day for Friday, 9th May 2003 -- After Van Gogh: Sunflowers on a Starry Night urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: I bought this really nice red vase and two large dyed red sunflowers and three small yellow. I do not know what I was thinking when I shot and re-shot all that red. The flowers blended a bit too much into the vase. So I did a little DA. Camera used: Fuji FP 2800 Geo. location: Philadelphia, PA Judge's comments: Where do I begin ... A "little" DA? 'Struth, Rob, it's clear from the image that it's been a lot of work to achieve this level of quality so I think you're being far too modest. For me, you have a talent for doing the right DA thing with the right image - and this time the jewel is the title! Cleverly done all round. You'll know by now that this is just the thing that really appeals to me especially when it's done like this.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, 8th May 2003 -- Stop Bugging Me urlLink Photographer: Jeffrey R. Bange Comments: None ... Camera used: Canon EOS 10D Geo. location: The Bronx Zoo Judge's comments: On a sort of "techie" side, the POTD today is brilliantly composed and selected and beautifully lit. The depth of field is, to my eye at least, perfect. That's that side of it: on the other, it's, well, it's just irresistible! What a truly cracking shot!! It's got a real feel of the little guy saying exactly what the title Jeffrey has given it. And if a photograph can give you that sort of feel", then it just has to be a winner. Many, many congratulations Jeffrey.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, 7th May 2003 -- Special Delivery urlLink Photographer: Margaret Satchell Comments: None ... Camera used: Olympus c4040 Geo. location: East 87th street, NYC Judge's comments: Today's POTD is indeed a Special Delivery, just as in the title!! A very beautifully crafted photo with the brickwork especially giving it some glorious lines. And how Margaret managed to find the colour scheme I'll never know! Everything matches, from the colours of the flowers in the vase, to the slight tint to the bricks to the deeper hue, I suppose it is, in the pathway and the wonderfully deep contrast of the curtains in the window. Probably the way the path falls away to the right isn't a purists way of doing things but for me, it just works absolutely sensationally. Truly a feast for the eyes.

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, 6th May 2003 -- Oaks urlLink Photographer: Kay Prather Comments: Beautiful huge oaks draped with moss and fern. These trees get huge and are so beautiful this time of the year. Camera used: Nikon CP 995 Geo. location: South, La Judge's comments: I must be getting to be a sucker for b&w photography! But this is such a beautiful picture it's irresistable. Wouldn't you just love to nestle down amongst those trees, listen to the birds and all and doze off in the sunshine ... the height of tranquility or what? :o) Congratulations Kay on a magnificent POTD.

Photo of the Day for Monday, 5th May 2003 -- Black and Light urlLink Photographer: Lyn Winans Comments: None ... Camera used: Olympus E20 Geo. location: Minden, ON Judge's comments: I found the lines in Lyns picture especially compelling. Also, the way that the stack and the rest of the building just seem to grow out of that diagonal has been very keenly observed and executed. Add in the light and altogether it's quite breathtaking. Black and white photography, always difficult I think, done exceptionally well.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, 4th May 2003 -- A Couple of Wild and Crazy Guys urlLink Photographer: Jim Carper Comments: Very recently hatched Tricolored Herons.....the first of the year that I've seen. Date: May 3, 2003 Camera used: Canon EOS 10d Geo. location: St. Augustine, Florida Judge's comments: I have absolutely nothing to say beyond "superb". The Birdman does it again.

Photo of the Day for Saturday, 17th May 2003 -- Feedin' Time urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: Well what's this all about then! Well I had purchased the slinkies and have tried to photograph them somewhat unsuccessfully in the past. This time I set them up with the largest against the three smaller. It's either a convergence of slinkies or some sort of abstract mammalian feeding process. Camera used: Fuji FP S602 Geo. location: Philadelphia, Pa Judge's comments: Can't you just feel these Slinkies in your hands? Feeling just like they really were alive. Then, to see Rob's photo and his idea that they might just be feedin' makes the imagination run wild ... Can't you just see little Slinkies everywhere snuggling up to their Slinkie Mother for their meal in some dark, dingy, quiet Slinkie home somewhere on the planet ... Rob!! Is this a new life form? Is this ??... could it be ??... First Contact! Is this a Close Encounter of the Third Kind?? .... A wonderful construction Rob, and a wild ride of the imagination to bring it to life. Marvellous!!

Photo of the Day for Friday, 16th May 2003 -- Compostion with Carnations urlLink Photographer: Gerda Grice Comments: Just playing around with some carnation blossoms a bit past their prime. Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Judge's comments: Beautifully composed in every respect, Gerda's POTD today powerfully demonstrates the Art of the imagination and shows that something gorgeous can be created from almost any object. I adore the way that the flowers seem to be very gently held in what I would guess, be a final embrace for them. For me, it's a kind of salute and thank you for the pleasure they have brought. The choice of colours for contrast is, I think, perfect and the angles and the symmetry in the photograph also make it a wonderful photograph.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, 15th May 2003 -- Waiting for the Pedicure urlLink Photographer: Mariette Geest Comments: Zzzzz this polarbear was snoring, so I had time to make up my own story what he was doing there. I think he was waiting for the pedicure. However, it gave me the opportunity to look at his feet. Isn't he adorable ;-) Camera used: Olympus C-730 UZ Geo. location: The Netherlands Judge's comments: On the face of it this is another POTD featuring a zoo animal but give it a closer look and you'll see that it really is on very different theme. In the first place, it's really well observed by Mariette and it's also a photograph that's full of great depth and detail, to the point that I've only just noticed that the bear is actually sound asleep!! I think I'm developing a strong taste for pictures that can keep my eye occupied all the time and this is one of them. Congratulations Mariette.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, 14th May 2003 -- Double Trouble urlLink Photographer: Jeffrey R. Bange Comments: This picture was taken at The Bronx Zoo in New York. SS 1/45, Aperture, 5.6, ISO 100, Focal Length 270mm Camera used: Canon EOS 10D Geo. location: New York Judge's comments: Jeffrey's winning photo is simply superb. I know that's an over-used word but when it's a true statement, what else is there to say? This picture is remarkable in it's content and in it's fabulous quality. It is also stunningly presented and overall there is a feeling of being privy to the conversation going on between the two animals. Any photograph that can provoke such thoughts just has to be a winner.

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, 13th May 2003 -- Whoops" urlLink Photographer: Deborah Walmsley Comments: None ... Camera used: Sony Cybershot DSC-F707 Date taken: May 06, 2003 Judge's comments: If I've learnt one thing in the last three month's it's that some photographs simply can't be ignored. There's a sort of quality about them and often I can't find the right words for it. Deborah's winner today is one of those "ignore me at your peril" pictures. I really can imagine it on one of those "inspirational" management posters with a suitable single-word title. "Challenge" perhaps. But above all, it's a gentle and fun photograph. I think it's great and another worthy POTD for Deborah.

Photo of the Day for Monday, 12th May 2003 -- Two Heads Are Better Than One urlLink Photographer: Jim Carper Comments: I was taken with the way these two alligator profiles created a full front on face. Gosh.....those drugs from the Sixties should have worn off by NOW, eh? :^) Camera used: Canon 10d w/Canon 100-400mm lens Geo. location: St. Augustine, Florida Judge's comments: A quite staggering optical illusion from Jim. Ingenious in fact. Hold on ...I've just realised .... I think this is an illusion ... it is an illusion ... isn't it? 'Struth, pass the pills someone ... I'm getting one of my headaches :o) Congratulations Jim on again, a very different style of POTD.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, 11th May 2003 -- Treats from the Trainer urlLink Photographer: Lesley Mattuchio Comments: My friend teaches beginning K-9 Agility classes and I went along to photograph the first class of this session. It was great fun watching the dogs learn to manuveur the obstacles on the course. They get rewarded each time they try a new obstacle. This English Setter had just jumped on the table where in a trial they must go to during their run and assume a down-stay for 30 seconds. Camera used: Canon EOS 10D Geo. location: Boston, MA. Judge's comments: For me, the really special thing about Lesley's photograph is that she's somehow managed to capture the pride and the sheer delight in the face of the owner/trainer and from what is a side-on view as well. Mind you, the setter doesn't look too bothered about what's going on! A lovely shot and a thoroughly deserving POTD.

Photo of the Day for Saturday, 24th May 2003 -- Blue Heron urlLink Photographer: Boris Myslovaty Comments: None ... Camera used: Fuji 4900z (Manual) Geo. location: Israel Judge's comments: A photograph that I feel is just wonderful to see. The detail, particularly of the feathers of the bird, the beautiful pose that Boris has captured, the lighting in general as well as the overall depth of field is really something. The only issue that I have with the image is - and I am in no way an expert, is that I'm not at all sure that this is a Blue Heron as the title suggests. Herons, I thought, were much bigger. Whatever, it doesn't detract in any way from what is a high quality POTD.

Photo of the Day for Friday, 23rd May 2003 -- Splash urlLink Photographer: Cheryl Meisel Comments: I am told by Rob this is a spider mum. I was doing some photos for Ebay which is a drag to me totally. I had this overhead work light over a white BG as it was night and our house is dark anyway inside. So I decided to make some use of this set-up and try some of the pretty cut flowers I just got for Mother's Day. This is what this one turned out like other then a bit of the ususal tweaks. Camera used: Sony 707 Geo. location: Erie, MI Judge's comments: I know from reading the postings in the forum that Cheryl's "Splash" has featured on at least one other site as a selection for their POTD competition. And that's no surprise to me at all because quality wins, hands down, every time. What a wonderful, staggering display of colour captured for us all to enjoy! And a beautifully simple but eloquent title which helps set the photo in the top class. Congratulations, Cheryl on a marvellous capture.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, 22nd May 2003 -- The Paws that Refreshes urlLink Photographer: Jeffrey R. Bange Comments: Picture was taken at the Bronx Zoo in New York on the opening weekend of their new exhibit Tiger Mountain. Camera Settings: SS 1/60, Aperture 5.6, ISO 100, Focal Length 350 mm Camera used: Canon EOS 10D Geo. location: New York Judge's comments: Without doubt the Tiger is my favourite animal of them all. I think they've a grace that's not matched anywhere else in the Kingdom and a serenity that seems to come with them knowing they are the best. Even when they're doing something very ordinary, like taking a drink as in Jeffrey's photo, they are simply sensational to look at. An ordinary moment in the day of a beautiful creature captured to make a beautiful picture.

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, 21st May 2003 -- Eye of the Sun urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: Bought another batch of Gerberas. I took macros of several. This one was just about the best so far. I like the gradation of the colors radiating out from the center. What I really like, though, is that nothing had to been done to this shot. The only processing was resizing for submission. Hope I can do some more like that. But if not, thank goodness for Photo Shop. Camera used: Fuji FP S602 Geo. location: Philadelphia, PA Judge's comments: I entirely agree with Rob that the colour radiating from the centre of the flower is the eye-catcher but I also found it impossible to ignore the way the subject is apparently lit from right to left. It's hard to believe that a photograph featuring (almost!) one colour or shade could be so strong. A great POTD showing once again, Nature in all it's glory.

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, 20th May 2003 -- On Tip-toes urlLink Photographer: Franziska Lang Comments: Doesn't it just look as if the seeds are standing on tip-toes? I picked the dandelion and (veeeerrry carefully) transported it home, then plucked off all but the two seeds and took the photo. I used black cardboard as the background but actually liked the brown color that resulted much better ... goes better with the dandelion itself I think. Camera used: Nikon D100 Geo. location: Virginia Judge's comments: Franziska has given us a truly wonderful study to enjoy. There's an enormous amount of detail to see and I was especially taken with the way the "feathers" on each of the seeds seem to shine against the background. But above all else, and I'm in total agreement with Franziska, the colour is simply gorgeous: the sepia brown really does work so well with the dandelion itself. The extreme care she took to get the picture is reflected in the photo.

Photo of the Day for Monday, 19th May 2003 -- Spring Skies urlLink Photographer: Lesley Mattuchio Comments: I just love the way the new colors of Spring trees seem to pop when the skies get black bringing a quick shower or just passing by. Camera used: Canon EOS 10D Geo. location: Malden, MA. Judge's comments: A stunning display of colours and contrasts is for me, the strongest and most fetching features of Lesley's photograph. But what really did catch my eye was the larger of the trees on the right hand side. If that tree isn't guarding the smaller trees with their precious bloom in front of it then I don't know what's what any more! A marvellous, imaginative and visually stunning feast for my old eyes. Wow...

Photo of the Day for Sunday, 18th May 2003 -- No Place to Hide urlLink Photographer: Sherry March Comments: None ... Camera used: Nikon Coolpix 995 Geo. location: Wellsville, PA Judge's comments: Sherry's winning photograph is a terrific capture. Birds are so difficult to get in exactly the right pose but Sherry has managed it. The colours are simply beautiful and the depth of field is great. And a real favourite of mine is to have a title that can make an essay of the picture in a very few words and this is one of them! The bird really does look like it's trying to find somewhere to hide - but in it's current surroundings, where?

Photo of the Day for June 1, 2003 -- Golden Beauty urlLink Photographer: J. Pedersen Comments: I was going past K-Mart and they had all kinds of pretty flowers for sale, naturally I had to stop and shoot a few pix. LOL Camera used: not given! Geo. location: San Diego, CA Judge's comments: I know we've seen our share of flower and inanimate object photos lately, but this one deserves the POTD regardless! The color saturation and bright nature of this photo is great. Also, the framing of the flower petals is excellent.

Goodbye, Bob! Bob Patterson, our trustworthy Photo of the Day judge, stepped down today to pursue a break and a variety of travels throughout Europe. He will remain in his position as one of the Shutterline Photography Forums moderators. I think Bob deserves a virtual round of applause for all the work he has done here at Shutterline. He's been a great photo judge, and he's a pretty good photographer as well ;) Starting tomorrow morning, I will resume my role as POTD judge. On an unrelated note, if you're one of those thousands of people who view the daily winner each day but don't participate in the contest -- how about trying your luck at it? Just urlLink become a member and then you'll be able to submit 30 photos per month to this contest.

Photo of the Day for Saturday, 31st May 2003 -- Nesting urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: They're back! Nesting on a bright golden background. They, apparently, sleep a lot more than me! LOL! Camera used: Fuji FP S602 Geo. location: Philadelphia, PA Judge's comments: I don't know what worries me more - the thought of Lash lip-synching to Cat Stevens or Slinkies nesting. Imagine someone having to clean out Lash's compound and there's a dark corner that no-one's been near for years. It's dry, full of spiders webs and the like ... you move aside a few, dried leaves and SMACK! in your face is a Mother Slinky!! Protecting her young !! You scream ... Lash hear's the noise - and comes to investigate! Goodness, the mind just boggles at the situation!! Oh yes, Rob's photograph. I like it.

Photo of the Day for Friday, 30th May 2003 -- Oooh, Baby, It's A Wild World urlLink Photographer: Jim Carper Comments: My pal, Lash, lip-synching to an old Cat Stevens' song. Photo taken May 14, 2003 at the Jacksonville Zoo. Camera used: Canon EOS 10d w/Canon 100-400mm lens Geo. location: Jacksonville, Florida Judge's comments: I simply cannot resist Jim's good buddy, Lash. He's a wonder and that's for sure. The expressions on his face - Lash that is, not Jim! - are just amazing! And Jim, the idea that Lash would sing along to, of all things, a Cat Stevens (sorry, a Yusuf Islam!) song is just a side splitter!! Izitso? Personally, I reckon that just as you took the picture he was thinking "This guy's a Foreigner - and maybe tasty!! I know, I'll wait in the Moonshadow, even until Morning has Broken - and then I'll have him." A great, great POTD, full of fun.

Photo of the Day for Thursday, 29th May 2003 -- Fireworks are Dandy urlLink Photographer: Cheryl Tessens Comments: I took this shot today.When I veiwed it on my monitor I thought that it would make a fine bl/wh due to the high contrasts.I converted it to black and white using PS7.It looks like fireworks in July to me. Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Geo. location: Holly,MI Judge's comments: I'm getting to be a black and white softie I believe!! I still think though that b&w has such immense competition from colour that it needs a real beauty to stand out from the "crowd" as it were but Cheryl's dandelions are just that. The picture itself has wonderful detail and what seems to me to be "strong" depth to it and I liked that a lot but it's Cheryl's observation that it looks like fireworks in July that made me look at it in an entirely different way. And I really agree with that - these are just like sparklers !!

Photo of the Day for Wednesday, 28th May 2003 -- Flea Market urlLink Photographer: Margaret Satchell Comments: the flea market disguised as "antique show" appears in every parking lot in about a 5 block area. ripe for a spontaneous photo shoot, this scene was one of a number i caught by serendipity but i thought it captured the scene pretty well. Camera used: Olympus c4040 Geo. location: new york city Judge's comments: I really do like the tremendous amount of detail that there is in Margaret's picture because it kept me occupied for a long while just looking at it all and taking it all in. And I took a long while to decide what the real subject of the photo is. Finally, I've convinced myself that it's actually the chandelier on the left - the guy is pointing to the wrong one! He's going to buy the wrong one! The bargain is on the left!! Quick, someone tell him!! :o)

Photo of the Day for Tuesday, 27th May 2003 -- Circle of Life urlLink Photographer: Bob Hall Comments: Young Blue Heron has a crab for lunch. Camera used: Sony DSC707 Geo. location: Texas City, Texas Judge's comments: I was particularly struck by Bob's photograph in that it just seems to me to be very well constructed indeed. The "rule of thirds" very often is exactly the right thing to do and it's been carried out brilliantly in today's POTD. As ever though, I'm also very much taken with Bob's wonderful title for his submission. This is a picture that vividly depicts that fact that so many creatures depend on others in the food chain for survival - it is the Circle of Life for sure.

Photo of the Day for Monday, 26th May 2003 -- Whitewater Paddler urlLink Photographer: Lyn Winans Comments: None ... Camera used: Olympus E20 Geo. location: Not known ... Judge's comments: Today's POTD is a superb action shot which is something we don't get a lot of on Shutterline. I just totally fell for this one from Lyn. It's got the lot for me. I can actually see the movement of the canoe through the water: I can feel the spray on my face: and the tension in the muscles of the rower - I'm there with him, struggling to keep a handle on my destiny!! And I can almost hear the rush of the water .... Superb, Lyn.

Photo of the Day for Sunday, 25th May 2003 -- Under Mom's Wing urlLink Photographer: Gerda Grice Comments: I shot this picture this afternoon at Edwards Gardens. I was so impressed with the park when we visited it on the weekend that I decided to pay it another visit today. This time, I came across mother goose, with her mate nearby, apparently just sitting on the grass. Then I noticed a bit of fluff peeking out from under one of her wings, Then there was movement under her wings near the centre of her back and a couple of bits of fluff appeared there. I kept watching and shooting and waiting, not sure of exactly what was happening, and this was one of the shots I got. Just a couple of minutes after I shot this, the mom got up--and 7 little goslings emerged from under her. Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Geo. location: Canada Judge's comments: A deliciously simple shot that captures a wonderful - and I would guess, a rare moment! I don't ever remember seeing anything like it before!! An totally charming POTD from Gerda which just goes to show that patience is not only a virtue but for a photographer, there's often a great reward. Makes it all worthwhile, don't you think?

Photo of the Day for June 7, 2003 -- Wavelengths Times 2 urlLink Photographer: Robert Mann Comments: On the corner of one of streets near where I work, there is a building that has burnished steel details. They run vertical about a story high and are located all around the building. I tried another of these straight on, but I did not have my big tripod with me. I was able to use my mini tripod against a street light and got reflections on two panels on the corner of the building. The colors and numbers of lines change as the lights on the street change and as vehicles go by. At night nothing else is reflected in the panels but these streams of colored light. Camera used: Fuji FP 2800 Geo. location: Philadelphia, PA Judge's comments: Creative photo, I love the contrast between the steel and the different bars of color.

Photo of the Day for June 6, 2003 -- On the Road urlLink Photographer: Franziska Lang Comments: Taken during a one-week photo journey through Iceland with my friend Barbara. This is the main road (and the better part of it) around the island. Many roads are dirt-tracks. I loved the wide open areas and the fact that there doesn't seem to be a single traffic light or barriers to the side of the road anywhere outside of Reykjavik. Camera used: Nikon D100 Geo. location: Iceland Judge's comments: Killer photo, Franziska! It's very powerful and the clear road ahead is inspiring -- seems like something Jack Kerouac would have written about. Everyone, I highly recommend that you click on the thumbnail to view the high-resolution image: this little preview image doesn't do the photo credit.

Photo of the Day for June 5, 2003 -- Convict Lake urlLink Photographer: J. Pedersen Comments: One of the many lakes we saw on vacation in the Eastern Sierras in California. Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Geo. location: California Judge's comments: My apologies for not posting earlier, I got awfully sidetracked today (read the forums for the full excuse... err story). This is another excellent photograph, just what I would expect from Ms. Pedersen. The framing is great, the reflection is artistic, and the rocks provide a great 'division' between land and water. Attention! Shutterline is currently in the evaluation process for a new Photo of the Day judge. Roughly every 3 months, we select one Shutterline member and teach them how to login to Shutterline's Administration Control Panel and post the daily photo. It's a lot of responsibility, and you have to be willing to post a new photo each day (you don't have to do it first thing in the morning, as long as you're consistent), but it's also a rewarding experience. The summer session is open right now -- from roughly June 9 to some time in late August. If you're interested, please urlLink contact us immediately with your full name, brief description of your photography experiences, and an explanation of why YOU deserve to be judge this time around.

Photo of the Day for June 4, 2003 -- Little Drops of Water urlLink Photographer: Gerda Grice Comments: I liked the look of these soft, sort of curly leaves (I have no idea what the plant is), and I especially liked the little water drops on the leaves. They were left over from a recent watering, I imagine. Camera used: Nikon CP 4500 Geo. location: not given! Judge's comments: A very nice, vivid raindrop photo. This is the kind of thing that would make an excellent wallpaper on my desktop! By the way, please don't forget to buy submission credits for the urlLink CA$H Contest and send in your photos... It's just like the POTD, except that the winner will receive a cool cash prize.

Photo of the Day for June 3, 2003 -- Lake Crescent urlLink Photographer: Kathy Cunningham Comments: No special settings. Nature provided the lighting. Camera used: Sony DSC-F717 Geo. location: not given! Judge's comments: An excellent photograph, I like the contrast between shore and rippling water, and the dock extending into the water adds to the composition. The foggy mountains are great, but I think this image could be even more powerful if you somehow got rid of the leaves at the top. Just a suggestion.

Photo of the Day for June 2, 2003 -- Sister Act urlLink Photographer: Lesley Mattuchio Comments: Jane and Judi are sisters and best friends and I felt this image of them portrayed the bond between them. Camera used: Canon EOS 10D Geo. location: Melrose, MA Judge's comments: It's been a while since we've seen a good black & white portrait. Here's one!

Photo of the Day for June 14, 2003 -- Doggy Love urlLink Photographer: Mariette Geest Comments: none Camera used: Fuji S2 Geo. location: not provided Judge's comments: Not very much information along with this photograph, but the bond between human and dog is obvious here. Nice portrait.

Photo of the Day for June 13, 2003 -- Old Oil Drums urlLink Photographer: Franziska Lang Comments: They were stacked in the corner of one of the harbors we traveled through ... converted to sepia to enhance the "old" feel. Camera used: Nikon D100 Geo. location: Iceland Judge's comments: Yet another POTD win for one of Franziska's Iceland photos, congratulations! I just loved how you took an ordinary object (oil drums) and gave them a unique look and feel.

Photo of the Day for June 12, 2003 -- Church Details urlLink Photographer: Franziska Lang Comments: Details of the gate and tower of an old Church in Iceland. Camera used: Nikon D100 Geo. location: Iceland Judge's comments: Striking geometry and textures, a simple but interesting photo. Good job!

Photo of the Day for June 11, 2003 -- Going Up? urlLink Photographer: Glenn Jensen Comments: Taken last week at El Morro National Monument midway through a hike to the top of the monument. The monument is, for the most part, a large sandstone bluff notable for the numerous inscriptions (made by Native American, European, and U.S. individuals) located around its base. This stairway, however, was carved out of the stone after the establishment of the monument to help mark the trail and prevent hikers from slipping off the edge of the bluff. I thought the white sandstone steps and dark storm clouds above would provide for an interesting black and white shot. I hope you agree! Camera Settings: f/8, 1/200 s, ISO 100 Camera used: Sony DSC-F707 Geo. location: Northwestern New Mexico Judge's comments: Great black&white composition, and thanks for providing such a detailed comments section for us! I particularly like how you shared the camera settings with us.

Photo of the Day for June 10, 2003 -- Sunset urlLink Photographer: Boris Myslovaty Camera used: Fuji 4900z Geo. location: Israel Judge's comments: Great sunset composition, but I wish you had told us something about this photograph and how you took it.

Photo of the Day for June 9, 2003 -- Beauty urlLink Photographer: J. Pedersen Comments: Inside Caesar's Palace at Tahoe Camera used: Sony DSC F707 Geo. location: California Judge's comments: An excellent black & white composition, the pseudo-Roman statue being an excellent centerpiece. Well done!

Photo of the Day for June 8, 2003 -- Green & Yellow Pasture urlLink Photographer: Dennis Castellano Comments: These colors are not altered in any way. This scene is right off the side of a mountain road in Western North Carolina. The colors were magnificent to behold, and the mule adds to the contrast don't you agree?
